speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: SCENE I. Before an alehouse on a heath.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Enter Hostess and SLY

speaker: SLY
text_entry: I'll pheeze you, in faith.

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: A pair of stocks, you rogue!

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Ye are a baggage: the Slys are no rogues; look in

speaker: SLY
text_entry: the chronicles; we came in with Richard Conqueror.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Therefore paucas pallabris; let the world slide: sessa!

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?

speaker: SLY
text_entry: No, not a denier. Go by, Jeronimy: go to thy cold

speaker: SLY
text_entry: bed, and warm thee.

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: I know my remedy; I must go fetch the

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: third--borough.

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I'll answer him

speaker: SLY
text_entry: by law: I'll not budge an inch, boy: let him come,

speaker: SLY
text_entry: and kindly.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Falls asleep

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Horns winded. Enter a Lord from hunting, with his train

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Brach Merriman, the poor cur is emboss'd;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And couple Clowder with the deep--mouth'd brach.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Saw'st thou not, boy, how Silver made it good

speaker: Lord
text_entry: At the hedge-corner, in the coldest fault?

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord;

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: He cried upon it at the merest loss

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: And twice to-day pick'd out the dullest scent:

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Thou art a fool: if Echo were as fleet,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I would esteem him worth a dozen such.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: But sup them well and look unto them all:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: To-morrow I intend to hunt again.

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: I will, my lord.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: What's here? one dead, or drunk? See, doth he breathe?

speaker: Second Huntsman
text_entry: He breathes, my lord. Were he not warm'd with ale,

speaker: Second Huntsman
text_entry: This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: O monstrous beast! how like a swine he lies!

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: What think you, if he were convey'd to bed,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Wrapp'd in sweet clothes, rings put upon his fingers,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: A most delicious banquet by his bed,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And brave attendants near him when he wakes,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Would not the beggar then forget himself?

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.

speaker: Second Huntsman
text_entry: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Then take him up and manage well the jest:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And hang it round with all my wanton pictures:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Procure me music ready when he wakes,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And if he chance to speak, be ready straight

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And with a low submissive reverence

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Say 'What is it your honour will command?'

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Let one attend him with a silver basin

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Full of rose-water and bestrew'd with flowers,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And say 'Will't please your lordship cool your hands?'

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Some one be ready with a costly suit

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And ask him what apparel he will wear;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Another tell him of his hounds and horse,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And that his lady mourns at his disease:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Persuade him that he hath been lunatic;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And when he says he is, say that he dreams,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: For he is nothing but a mighty lord.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: This do and do it kindly, gentle sirs:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: It will be pastime passing excellent,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: If it be husbanded with modesty.

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part,

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: As he shall think by our true diligence

speaker: First Huntsman
text_entry: He is no less than what we say he is.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Take him up gently and to bed with him;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And each one to his office when he wakes.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Some bear out SLY. A trumpet sounds

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Sirrah, go see what trumpet 'tis that sounds:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Exit Servingman

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Belike, some noble gentleman that means,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Travelling some journey, to repose him here.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Re-enter Servingman

speaker: Lord
text_entry: How now! who is it?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: An't please your honour, players

speaker: Servant
text_entry: That offer service to your lordship.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Bid them come near.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Enter Players

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Now, fellows, you are welcome.

speaker: Players
text_entry: We thank your honour.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

speaker: A Player
text_entry: So please your lordship to accept our duty.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: With all my heart. This fellow I remember,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Since once he play'd a farmer's eldest son:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: 'Twas where you woo'd the gentlewoman so well:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I have forgot your name; but, sure, that part

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Was aptly fitted and naturally perform'd.

speaker: A Player
text_entry: I think 'twas Soto that your honour means.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: 'Tis very true: thou didst it excellent.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Well, you are come to me in a happy time;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: The rather for I have some sport in hand

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Wherein your cunning can assist me much.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: There is a lord will hear you play to-night:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: But I am doubtful of your modesties;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior,--

speaker: Lord
text_entry: For yet his honour never heard a play--

speaker: Lord
text_entry: You break into some merry passion

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And so offend him; for I tell you, sirs,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: If you should smile he grows impatient.

speaker: A Player
text_entry: Fear not, my lord: we can contain ourselves,

speaker: A Player
text_entry: Were he the veriest antic in the world.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And give them friendly welcome every one:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Let them want nothing that my house affords.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Exit one with the Players

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Sirrah, go you to Barthol'mew my page,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And see him dress'd in all suits like a lady:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: That done, conduct him to the drunkard's chamber;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And call him 'madam,' do him obeisance.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Tell him from me, as he will win my love,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: He bear himself with honourable action,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Such as he hath observed in noble ladies

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Unto their lords, by them accomplished:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Such duty to the drunkard let him do

speaker: Lord
text_entry: With soft low tongue and lowly courtesy,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And say 'What is't your honour will command,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Wherein your lady and your humble wife

speaker: Lord
text_entry: May show her duty and make known her love?'

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And with declining head into his bosom,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Bid him shed tears, as being overjoy'd

speaker: Lord
text_entry: To see her noble lord restored to health,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Who for this seven years hath esteem'd him

speaker: Lord
text_entry: No better than a poor and loathsome beggar:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And if the boy have not a woman's gift

speaker: Lord
text_entry: To rain a shower of commanded tears,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: An onion will do well for such a shift,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Which in a napkin being close convey'd

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Shall in despite enforce a watery eye.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: See this dispatch'd with all the haste thou canst:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Anon I'll give thee more instructions.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Exit a Servingman

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I know the boy will well usurp the grace,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Voice, gait and action of a gentlewoman:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I long to hear him call the drunkard husband,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And how my men will stay themselves from laughter

speaker: Lord
text_entry: When they do homage to this simple peasant.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I'll in to counsel them; haply my presence

speaker: Lord
text_entry: May well abate the over-merry spleen

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Which otherwise would grow into extremes.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Lord
text_entry: SCENE II. A bedchamber in the Lord's house.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Enter aloft SLY, with Attendants; some with apparel, others with basin and ewer and appurtenances; and Lord

speaker: SLY
text_entry: For God's sake, a pot of small ale.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Will't please your lordship drink a cup of sack?

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Will't please your honour taste of these conserves?

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: What raiment will your honour wear to-day?

speaker: SLY
text_entry: I am Christophero Sly; call not me 'honour' nor

speaker: SLY
text_entry: 'lordship:' I ne'er drank sack in my life; and if

speaker: SLY
text_entry: you give me any conserves, give me conserves of

speaker: SLY
text_entry: beef: ne'er ask me what raiment I'll wear; for I

speaker: SLY
text_entry: have no more doublets than backs, no more stockings

speaker: SLY
text_entry: than legs, nor no more shoes than feet; nay,

speaker: SLY
text_entry: sometimes more feet than shoes, or such shoes as my

speaker: SLY
text_entry: toes look through the over-leather.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour!

speaker: Lord
text_entry: O, that a mighty man of such descent,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Of such possessions and so high esteem,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Should be infused with so foul a spirit!

speaker: SLY
text_entry: What, would you make me mad? Am not I Christopher

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Sly, old Sly's son of Burtonheath, by birth a

speaker: SLY
text_entry: pedlar, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation a

speaker: SLY
text_entry: bear-herd, and now by present profession a tinker?

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Ask Marian Hacket, the fat ale-wife of Wincot, if

speaker: SLY
text_entry: she know me not: if she say I am not fourteen pence

speaker: SLY
text_entry: on the score for sheer ale, score me up for the

speaker: SLY
text_entry: lyingest knave in Christendom. What! I am not

speaker: SLY
text_entry: bestraught: here's--

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: O, this it is that makes your lady mourn!

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: O, this is it that makes your servants droop!

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Look how thy servants do attend on thee,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Each in his office ready at thy beck.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Wilt thou have music? hark! Apollo plays,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Music

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And twenty caged nightingales do sing:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Or wilt thou sleep? we'll have thee to a couch

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed

speaker: Lord
text_entry: On purpose trimm'd up for Semiramis.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Say thou wilt walk; we will bestrew the ground:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Or wilt thou ride? thy horses shall be trapp'd,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Their harness studded all with gold and pearl.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Dost thou love hawking? thou hast hawks will soar

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Above the morning lark or wilt thou hunt?

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Say thou wilt course; thy greyhounds are as swift

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: As breathed stags, ay, fleeter than the roe.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Dost thou love pictures? we will fetch thee straight

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Adonis painted by a running brook,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: And Cytherea all in sedges hid,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Which seem to move and wanton with her breath,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Even as the waving sedges play with wind.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: We'll show thee Io as she was a maid,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And how she was beguiled and surprised,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: As lively painted as the deed was done.

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood,

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds,

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep,

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Than any woman in this waning age.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Like envious floods o'er-run her lovely face,

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: She was the fairest creature in the world;

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: And yet she is inferior to none.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Am I a lord? and have I such a lady?

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Or do I dream? or have I dream'd till now?

speaker: SLY
text_entry: I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak;

speaker: SLY
text_entry: I smell sweet savours and I feel soft things:

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Upon my life, I am a lord indeed

speaker: SLY
text_entry: And not a tinker nor Christophero Sly.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Well, bring our lady hither to our sight;

speaker: SLY
text_entry: And once again, a pot o' the smallest ale.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Will't please your mightiness to wash your hands?

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: O, how we joy to see your wit restored!

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: O, that once more you knew but what you are!

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: These fifteen years you have been in a dream;

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Or when you waked, so waked as if you slept.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: These fifteen years! by my fay, a goodly nap.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: But did I never speak of all that time?

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: O, yes, my lord, but very idle words:

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: For though you lay here in this goodly chamber,

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Yet would you say ye were beaten out of door;

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: And rail upon the hostess of the house;

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: And say you would present her at the leet,

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Because she brought stone jugs and no seal'd quarts:

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Ay, the woman's maid of the house.

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid,

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Nor no such men as you have reckon'd up,

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: As Stephen Sly and did John Naps of Greece

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: And twenty more such names and men as these

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Which never were nor no man ever saw.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: I thank thee: thou shalt not lose by it.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Enter the Page as a lady, with attendants

speaker: Page
text_entry: How fares my noble lord?

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Marry, I fare well for here is cheer enough.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Where is my wife?

speaker: Page
text_entry: Here, noble lord: what is thy will with her?

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Are you my wife and will not call me husband?

speaker: SLY
text_entry: My men should call me 'lord:' I am your goodman.

speaker: Page
text_entry: My husband and my lord, my lord and husband;

speaker: Page
text_entry: I am your wife in all obedience.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: I know it well. What must I call her?

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Madam.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Al'ce madam, or Joan madam?

speaker: Lord
text_entry: 'Madam,' and nothing else: so lords

speaker: Lord
text_entry: call ladies.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Madam wife, they say that I have dream'd

speaker: SLY
text_entry: And slept above some fifteen year or more.

speaker: Page
text_entry: Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me,

speaker: Page
text_entry: Being all this time abandon'd from your bed.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: 'Tis much. Servants, leave me and her alone.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Madam, undress you and come now to bed.

speaker: Page
text_entry: Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you

speaker: Page
text_entry: To pardon me yet for a night or two,

speaker: Page
text_entry: Or, if not so, until the sun be set:

speaker: Page
text_entry: For your physicians have expressly charged,

speaker: Page
text_entry: In peril to incur your former malady,

speaker: Page
text_entry: That I should yet absent me from your bed:

speaker: Page
text_entry: I hope this reason stands for my excuse.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Ay, it stands so that I may hardly

speaker: SLY
text_entry: tarry so long. But I would be loath to fall into

speaker: SLY
text_entry: my dreams again: I will therefore tarry in

speaker: SLY
text_entry: despite of the flesh and the blood.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your honour's players, heating your amendment,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Are come to play a pleasant comedy;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: For so your doctors hold it very meet,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Seeing too much sadness hath congeal'd your blood,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Therefore they thought it good you hear a play

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And frame your mind to mirth and merriment,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Marry, I will, let them play it. Is not a

speaker: SLY
text_entry: comondy a Christmas gambold or a tumbling-trick?

speaker: Page
text_entry: No, my good lord; it is more pleasing stuff.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: What, household stuff?

speaker: Page
text_entry: It is a kind of history.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Well, well see't. Come, madam wife, sit by my side

speaker: SLY
text_entry: and let the world slip: we shall ne'er be younger.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Flourish

speaker: SLY
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: SLY
text_entry: SCENE I. Padua. A public place.

speaker: SLY
text_entry: Enter LUCENTIO and his man TRANIO

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Tranio, since for the great desire I had

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: To see fair Padua, nursery of arts,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: I am arrived for fruitful Lombardy,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: The pleasant garden of great Italy;

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And by my father's love and leave am arm'd

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: With his good will and thy good company,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: My trusty servant, well approved in all,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Here let us breathe and haply institute

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: A course of learning and ingenious studies.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Pisa renown'd for grave citizens

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Gave me my being and my father first,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: A merchant of great traffic through the world,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Vincetino come of Bentivolii.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Vincetino's son brought up in Florence

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: It shall become to serve all hopes conceived,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds:

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And therefore, Tranio, for the time I study,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Virtue and that part of philosophy

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Will I apply that treats of happiness

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: By virtue specially to be achieved.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Tell me thy mind; for I have Pisa left

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And am to Padua come, as he that leaves

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: A shallow plash to plunge him in the deep

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Mi perdonato, gentle master mine,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I am in all affected as yourself;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Glad that you thus continue your resolve

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Only, good master, while we do admire

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: This virtue and this moral discipline,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Let's be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Or so devote to Aristotle's cheques

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: As Ovid be an outcast quite abjured:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Balk logic with acquaintance that you have

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And practise rhetoric in your common talk;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Music and poesy use to quicken you;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: The mathematics and the metaphysics,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: In brief, sir, study what you most affect.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: If, Biondello, thou wert come ashore,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: We could at once put us in readiness,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And take a lodging fit to entertain

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Such friends as time in Padua shall beget.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: But stay a while: what company is this?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Master, some show to welcome us to town.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Enter BAPTISTA, KATHARINA, BIANCA, GREMIO, and HORTENSIO. LUCENTIO and TRANIO stand by

speaker: BAPTISTA

text_entry: Gentlemen, that I may soon make good

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible

text_entry: O Tranio, till I found it to be true,

text_entry: But see, while idly I stood looking on,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: I found the effect of love in idleness:

speaker: LUCENTIO

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: That art to me as secret and as dear

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: As Anna to the queen of Carthage was,

speaker: LUCENTIO

text_entry: Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst;

text_entry: Master, it is no time to chide you now;

text_entry: Affection is not rated from the heart:

speaker: TRANIO

text_entry: Master, you look'd so longly on the maid,

text_entry: Perhaps you mark'd not what's the pith of all.

speaker: LUCENTIO

text_entry: Tell me her father's name and 'tis enough;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For I will board her, though she chide as loud

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Her father is Baptista Minola,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: An affable and courteous gentleman:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Her name is Katharina Minola,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Renown'd in Padua for her scolding tongue.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I know her father, though I know not her;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And he knew my deceased father well.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And therefore let me be thus bold with you

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To give you over at this first encounter,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Unless you will accompany me thither.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I pray you, sir, let him go while the humour lasts.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: O' my word, an she knew him as well as I do, she

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: would think scolding would do little good upon him:

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: she may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so:

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: why, that's nothing; an he begin once, he'll rail in

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: his rope-tricks. I'll tell you what sir, an she

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: her face and so disfigure her with it that she

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: You know him not, sir.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: For in Baptista's keep my treasure is:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: He hath the jewel of my life in hold,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: His youngest daughter, beautiful Binaca,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And her withholds from me and other more,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Suitors to her and rivals in my love,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Supposing it a thing impossible,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: For those defects I have before rehearsed,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: That ever Katharina will be woo'd;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Therefore this order hath Baptista ta'en,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: That none shall have access unto Bianca

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Till Katharina the curst have got a husband.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Katharina the curst!

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: A title for a maid of all titles the worst.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And offer me disguised in sober robes

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: To old Baptista as a schoolmaster

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: That so I may, by this device, at least

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Have leave and leisure to make love to her

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And unsuspected court her by herself.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Here's no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: how the young folks lay their heads together!

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Enter GREMIO, and LUCENTIO disguised

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Master, master, look about you: who goes there, ha?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Peace, Grumio! it is the rival of my love.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Petruchio, stand by a while.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: A proper stripling and an amorous!

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: O, very well; I have perused the note.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Hark you, sir: I'll have them very fairly bound:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: All books of love, see that at any hand;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And see you read no other lectures to her:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: You understand me: over and beside

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Signior Baptista's liberality,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: I'll mend it with a largess. Take your paper too,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And let me have them very well perfumed

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: For she is sweeter than perfume itself

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: To whom they go to. What will you read to her?

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Whate'er I read to her, I'll plead for you

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: As for my patron, stand you so assured,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: As firmly as yourself were still in place:

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Yea, and perhaps with more successful words

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Than you, unless you were a scholar, sir.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: O this learning, what a thing it is!

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: O this woodcock, what an ass it is!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Peace, sirrah!

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Grumio, mum! God save you, Signior Gremio.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: I promised to inquire carefully

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And by good fortune I have lighted well

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: On this young man, for learning and behavior

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Fit for her turn, well read in poetry

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And other books, good ones, I warrant ye.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: 'Tis well; and I have met a gentleman

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Hath promised me to help me to another,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: A fine musician to instruct our mistress;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: So shall I no whit be behind in duty

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Beloved of me; and that my deeds shall prove.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: And that his bags shall prove.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Gremio, 'tis now no time to vent our love:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Listen to me, and if you speak me fair,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: I'll tell you news indifferent good for either.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Upon agreement from us to his liking,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Will undertake to woo curst Katharina,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: So said, so done, is well.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I know she is an irksome brawling scold:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: No, say'st me so, friend? What countryman?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Born in Verona, old Antonio's son:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: My father dead, my fortune lives for me;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And I do hope good days and long to see.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: O sir, such a life, with such a wife, were strange!

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: But if you have a stomach, to't i' God's name:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: You shall have me assisting you in all.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: But will you woo this wild-cat?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Will I live?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Will he woo her? ay, or I'll hang her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why came I hither but to that intent?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Think you a little din can daunt mine ears?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Have I not in my time heard lions roar?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Have I not heard the sea puff'd up with winds

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Rage like an angry boar chafed with sweat?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Have I not heard great ordnance in the field,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And heaven's artillery thunder in the skies?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Have I not in a pitched battle heard

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Loud 'larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets' clang?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And do you tell me of a woman's tongue,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That gives not half so great a blow to hear

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As will a chestnut in a farmer's fire?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Tush, tush! fear boys with bugs.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: For he fears none.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Hortensio, hark:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: This gentleman is happily arrived,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: I promised we would be contributors

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And bear his charging of wooing, whatsoe'er.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And so we will, provided that he win her.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Enter TRANIO brave, and BIONDELLO

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Gentlemen, God save you. If I may be bold,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest way

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: He that has the two fair daughters: is't he you mean?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Even he, Biondello.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Hark you, sir; you mean not her to--

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Perhaps, him and her, sir: what have you to do?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I love no chiders, sir. Biondello, let's away.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Well begun, Tranio.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Sir, a word ere you go;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And if I be, sir, is it any offence?

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: No; if without more words you will get you hence.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: For me as for you?

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: But so is not she.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: For what reason, I beseech you?

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: For this reason, if you'll know,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: That she's the choice love of Signior Gremio.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Softly, my masters! if you be gentlemen,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Do me this right; hear me with patience.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Baptista is a noble gentleman,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To whom my father is not all unknown;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And were his daughter fairer than she is,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: She may more suitors have and me for one.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Fair Leda's daughter had a thousand wooers;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Then well one more may fair Bianca have:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And so she shall; Lucentio shall make one,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: What! this gentleman will out-talk us all.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Sir, give him head: I know he'll prove a jade.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Sir, let me be so bold as ask you,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Did you yet ever see Baptista's daughter?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: No, sir; but hear I do that he hath two,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: The one as famous for a scolding tongue

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: As is the other for beauteous modesty.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Sir, sir, the first's for me; let her go by.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Yea, leave that labour to great Hercules;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Sir, understand you this of me in sooth:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: The younges t daughter whom you hearken for

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Her father keeps from all access of suitors,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And will not promise her to any man

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Until the elder sister first be wed:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: The younger then is free and not before.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: If it be so, sir, that you are the man

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Must stead us all and me amongst the rest,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And if you break the ice and do this feat,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Achieve the elder, set the younger free

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: For our access, whose hap shall be to have her

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Will not so graceless be to be ingrate.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Sir, you say well and well you do conceive;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And since you do profess to be a suitor,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: To whom we all rest generally beholding.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Sir, I shall not be slack: in sign whereof,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Please ye we may contrive this afternoon,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And quaff carouses to our mistress' health,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And do as adversaries do in law,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: O excellent motion! Fellows, let's be gone.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: The motion's good indeed and be it so,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: SCENE I. Padua. A room in BAPTISTA'S house.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Enter KATHARINA and BIANCA

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: To make a bondmaid and a slave of me;

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: That I disdain: but for these other gawds,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Unbind my hands, I'll pull them off myself,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Yea, all my raiment, to my petticoat;

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Or what you will command me will I do,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: So well I know my duty to my elders.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Of all thy suitors, here I charge thee, tell

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Whom thou lovest best: see thou dissemble not.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Believe me, sister, of all the men alive

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: I never yet beheld that special face

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Which I could fancy more than any other.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Minion, thou liest. Is't not Hortensio?

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: If you affect him, sister, here I swear

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: I'll plead for you myself, but you shall have

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: him.

text_entry: O then, belike, you fancy riches more:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: You will have Gremio to keep you fair.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Is it for him you do envy me so?

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Nay then you jest, and now I well perceive

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: You have but jested with me all this while:

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: If that be jest, then all the rest was so.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Strikes her

speaker: KATHARINA

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Why, how now, dame! whence grows this insolence?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Bianca, stand aside. Poor girl! she weeps.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: For shame, thou helding of a devilish spirit,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: When did she cross thee with a bitter word?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Her silence flouts me, and I'll be revenged.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Flies after BIANCA

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: What, in my sight? Bianca, get thee in.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Exit BIANCA

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: What, will you not suffer me? Nay, now I see

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: She is your treasure, she must have a husband;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I must dance bare-foot on her wedding day

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And for your love to her lead apes in hell.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Talk not to me: I will go sit and weep

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Till I can find occasion of revenge.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: But who comes here?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Enter GREMIO, LUCENTIO in the habit of a mean man;  PETRUCHIO, with HORTENSIO as a musician; and TRANIO, with BIONDELLO bearing a lute and books

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Good morrow, neighbour Baptista.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Good morrow, neighbour Gremio.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: God save you, gentlemen!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And you, good sir! Pray, have you not a daughter

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Call'd Katharina, fair and virtuous?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I have a daughter, sir, called Katharina.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: You are too blunt: go to it orderly.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You wrong me, Signior Gremio: give me leave.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I am a gentleman of Verona, sir,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That, hearing of her beauty and her wit,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Her affability and bashful modesty,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Am bold to show myself a forward guest

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Within your house, to make mine eye the witness

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Of that report which I so oft have heard.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And, for an entrance to my entertainment,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I do present you with a man of mine,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Presenting HORTENSIO

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Cunning in music and the mathematics,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To instruct her fully in those sciences,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Whereof I know she is not ignorant:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Accept of him, or else you do me wrong:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: His name is Licio, born in Mantua.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: You're welcome, sir; and he, for your good sake.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: But for my daughter Katharina, this I know,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: She is not for your turn, the more my grief.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I see you do not mean to part with her,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Or else you like not of my company.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Mistake me not; I speak but as I find.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Whence are you, sir? what may I call your name?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Petruchio is my name; Antonio's son,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: A man well known throughout all Italy.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I know him well: you are welcome for his sake.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Let us, that are poor petitioners, speak too:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Baccare! you are marvellous forward.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O, pardon me, Signior Gremio; I would fain be doing.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: I doubt it not, sir; but you will curse your

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: wooing. Neighbour, this is a gift very grateful, I am

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: sure of it. To express the like kindness, myself,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: that have been more kindly beholding to you than

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: any, freely give unto you this young scholar,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Presenting LUCENTIO

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: that hath been long studying at Rheims; as cunning

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: in Greek, Latin, and other languages, as the other

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: in music and mathematics: his name is Cambio; pray,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: accept his service.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Welcome, good Cambio.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: To TRANIO

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: may I be so bold to know the cause of your coming?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: That, being a stranger in this city here,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Do make myself a suitor to your daughter,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: In the preferment of the eldest sister.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: This liberty is all that I request,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: That, upon knowledge of my parentage,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I may have welcome 'mongst the rest that woo

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And free access and favour as the rest:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And, toward the education of your daughters,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I here bestow a simple instrument,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And this small packet of Greek and Latin books:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: If you accept them, then their worth is great.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Lucentio is your name; of whence, I pray?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Of Pisa, sir; son to Vincentio.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: A mighty man of Pisa; by report

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I know him well: you are very welcome, sir,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Take you the lute, and you the set of books;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: You shall go see your pupils presently.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Holla, within!

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Sirrah, lead these gentlemen

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: To my daughters; and tell them both,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: These are their tutors: bid them use them well.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Exit Servant, with LUCENTIO and HORTENSIO, BIONDELLO following

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: We will go walk a little in the orchard,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And then to dinner. You are passing welcome,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And so I pray you all to think yourselves.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And every day I cannot come to woo.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You knew my father well, and in him me,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Left solely heir to all his lands and goods,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Which I have better'd rather than decreased:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Then tell me, if I get your daughter's love,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What dowry shall I have with her to wife?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: After my death the one half of my lands,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And in possession twenty thousand crowns.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And, for that dowry, I'll assure her of

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Her widowhood, be it that she survive me,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: In all my lands and leases whatsoever:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That covenants may be kept on either hand.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Ay, when the special thing is well obtain'd,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: That is, her love; for that is all in all.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, that is nothing: for I tell you, father,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I am as peremptory as she proud-minded;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And where two raging fires meet together

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: They do consume the thing that feeds their fury:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Though little fire grows great with little wind,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: So I to her and so she yields to me;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For I am rough and woo not like a babe.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed!

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: But be thou arm'd for some unhappy words.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Ay, to the proof; as mountains are for winds,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That shake not, though they blow perpetually.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Re-enter HORTENSIO, with his head broke

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: How now, my friend! why dost thou look so pale?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: I think she'll sooner prove a soldier

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Why, no; for she hath broke the lute to me.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: I did but tell her she mistook her frets,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And bow'd her hand to teach her fingering;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: When, with a most impatient devilish spirit,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: 'Frets, call you these?' quoth she; 'I'll fume

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: with them:'

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And, with that word, she struck me on the head,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And through the instrument my pate made way;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And there I stood amazed for a while,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: As on a pillory, looking through the lute;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: While she did call me rascal fiddler

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And twangling Jack; with twenty such vile terms,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: As had she studied to misuse me so.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I love her ten times more than e'er I did:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O, how I long to have some chat with her!

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Well, go with me and be not so discomfited:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Proceed in practise with my younger daughter;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: She's apt to learn and thankful for good turns.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Signior Petruchio, will you go with us,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I pray you do.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Exeunt all but PETRUCHIO

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I will attend her here,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And woo her with some spirit when she comes.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Say that she rail; why then I'll tell her plain

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: She sings as sweetly as a nightingale:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Say that she frown, I'll say she looks as clear

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As morning roses newly wash'd with dew:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Say she be mute and will not speak a word;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Then I'll commend her volubility,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And say she uttereth piercing eloquence:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As though she bid me stay by her a week:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: If she deny to wed, I'll crave the day

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: When I shall ask the banns and when be married.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But here she comes; and now, Petruchio, speak.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Enter KATHARINA

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Good morrow, Kate; for that's your name, I hear.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: They call me Katharina that do talk of me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You lie, in faith; for you are call'd plain Kate,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And bonny Kate and sometimes Kate the curst;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Take this of me, Kate of my consolation;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Hearing thy mildness praised in every town,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Moved! in good time: let him that moved you hither

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Remove you hence: I knew you at the first

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: You were a moveable.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, what's a moveable?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: A join'd-stool.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: No such jade as you, if me you mean.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Alas! good Kate, I will not burden thee;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For, knowing thee to be but young and light--

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Too light for such a swain as you to catch;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Should be! should--buzz!

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O slow-wing'd turtle! shall a buzzard take thee?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Come, come, you wasp; i' faith, you are too angry.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: My remedy is then, to pluck it out.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Who knows not where a wasp does

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: wear his sting? In his tail.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: In his tongue.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Whose tongue?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Yours, if you talk of tails: and so farewell.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What, with my tongue in your tail? nay, come again,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Good Kate; I am a gentleman.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: That I'll try.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: She strikes him

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I swear I'll cuff you, if you strike again.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: So may you lose your arms:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: If you strike me, you are no gentleman;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: A herald, Kate? O, put me in thy books!

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: What is your crest? a coxcomb?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: No cock of mine; you crow too like a craven.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Nay, come, Kate, come; you must not look so sour.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, here's no crab; and therefore look not sour.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: There is, there is.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Then show it me.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Had I a glass, I would.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What, you mean my face?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Well aim'd of such a young one.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Yet you are wither'd.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: 'Tis with cares.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I care not.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth you scape not so.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I chafe you, if I tarry: let me go.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: No, not a whit: I find you passing gentle.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: 'Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And now I find report a very liar;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But slow in speech, yet sweet as spring-time flowers:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But thou with mildness entertain'st thy wooers,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: With gentle conference, soft and affable.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O slanderous world! Kate like the hazel-twig

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Is straight and slender and as brown in hue

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As hazel nuts and sweeter than the kernels.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O, let me see thee walk: thou dost not halt.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Did ever Dian so become a grove

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As Kate this chamber with her princely gait?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O, be thou Dian, and let her be Kate;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful!

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Where did you study all this goodly speech?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: It is extempore, from my mother-wit.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: A witty mother! witless else her son.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Am I not wise?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Yes; keep you warm.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Marry, so I mean, sweet Katharina, in thy bed:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And therefore, setting all this chat aside,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That you shall be my wife; your dowry 'greed on;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And, Will you, nill you, I will marry you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thy beauty, that doth make me like thee well,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thou must be married to no man but me;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For I am he am born to tame you Kate,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Conformable as other household Kates.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Here comes your father: never make denial;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I must and will have Katharina to my wife.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Re-enter BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and TRANIO

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: How but well, sir? how but well?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: It were impossible I should speed amiss.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Why, how now, daughter Katharina! in your dumps?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Call you me daughter? now, I promise you

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: You have show'd a tender fatherly regard,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: To wish me wed to one half lunatic;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: A mad-cup ruffian and a swearing Jack,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That talk'd of her, have talk'd amiss of her:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: If she be curst, it is for policy,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For she's not froward, but modest as the dove;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: She is not hot, but temperate as the morn;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For patience she will prove a second Grissel,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And Roman Lucrece for her chastity:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That upon Sunday is the wedding-day.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I'll see thee hang'd on Sunday first.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Hark, Petruchio; she says she'll see thee

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: hang'd first.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Is this your speeding? nay, then, good night our part!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Be patient, gentlemen; I choose her for myself:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: If she and I be pleased, what's that to you?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: 'Tis bargain'd 'twixt us twain, being alone,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That she shall still be curst in company.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I tell you, 'tis incredible to believe

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: How much she loves me: O, the kindest Kate!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: She hung about my neck; and kiss on kiss

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That in a twink she won me to her love.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O, you are novices! 'tis a world to see,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: How tame, when men and women are alone,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Give me thy hand, Kate: I will unto Venice,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding-day.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I will be sure my Katharina shall be fine.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I know not what to say: but give me your hands;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: God send you joy, Petruchio! 'tis a match.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Amen, say we: we will be witnesses.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I will to Venice; Sunday comes apace:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: We will have rings and things and fine array;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And kiss me, Kate, we will be married o'Sunday.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Exeunt PETRUCHIO and KATHARINA severally

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And venture madly on a desperate mart.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: 'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: 'Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: The gain I seek is, quiet in the match.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: But now, Baptists, to your younger daughter:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Now is the day we long have looked for:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And I am one that love Bianca more

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Than words can witness, or your thoughts can guess.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: But thine doth fry.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Skipper, stand back: 'tis age that nourisheth.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Content you, gentlemen: I will compound this strife:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: 'Tis deeds must win the prize; and he of both

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: That can assure my daughter greatest dower

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Shall have my Bianca's love.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Say, Signior Gremio, What can you assure her?

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: First, as you know, my house within the city

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Is richly furnished with plate and gold;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: In ivory coffers I have stuff'd my crowns;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: In cypress chests my arras counterpoints,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Costly apparel, tents, and canopies,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Fine linen, Turkey cushions boss'd with pearl,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Valance of Venice gold in needlework,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Pewter and brass and all things that belong

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: To house or housekeeping: then, at my farm

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Sixscore fat oxen standing in my stalls,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And all things answerable to this portion.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Myself am struck in years, I must confess;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And if I die to-morrow, this is hers,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: If whilst I live she will be only mine.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: That 'only' came well in. Sir, list to me:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I am my father's heir and only son:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: If I may have your daughter to my wife,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I'll leave her houses three or four as good,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Within rich Pisa walls, as any one

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Old Signior Gremio has in Padua;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Besides two thousand ducats by the year

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: What, have I pinch'd you, Signior Gremio?

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Two thousand ducats by the year of land!

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: My land amounts not to so much in all:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: That she shall have; besides an argosy

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: That now is lying in Marseilles' road.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: What, have I choked you with an argosy?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Gremio, 'tis known my father hath no less

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Than three great argosies; besides two galliases,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And twelve tight galleys: these I will assure her,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And twice as much, whate'er thou offer'st next.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Nay, I have offer'd all, I have no more;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And she can have no more than all I have:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: If you like me, she shall have me and mine.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Why, then the maid is mine from all the world,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: By your firm promise: Gremio is out-vied.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I must confess your offer is the best;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And, let your father make her the assurance,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: She is your own; else, you must pardon me,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: if you should die before him, where's her dower?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: That's but a cavil: he is old, I young.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And may not young men die, as well as old?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Well, gentlemen,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I am thus resolved: on Sunday next you know

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: My daughter Katharina is to be married:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Be bride to you, if you this assurance;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: If not, Signior Gremio:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And so, I take my leave, and thank you both.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Adieu, good neighbour.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Exit BAPTISTA

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Now I fear thee not:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: To give thee all, and in his waning age

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Set foot under thy table: tut, a toy!

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: A vengeance on your crafty wither'd hide!

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Yet I have faced it with a card of ten.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: 'Tis in my head to do my master good:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I see no reason but supposed Lucentio

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Must get a father, call'd 'supposed Vincentio;'

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And that's a wonder: fathers commonly

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Do get their children; but in this case of wooing,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: SCENE I. Padua. BAPTISTA'S house.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Enter LUCENTIO, HORTENSIO, and BIANCA

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Fiddler, forbear; you grow too forward, sir:

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Have you so soon forgot the entertainment

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Her sister Katharina welcomed you withal?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: But, wrangling pedant, this is

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: The patroness of heavenly harmony:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Then give me leave to have prerogative;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And when in music we have spent an hour,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Preposterous ass, that never read so far

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: To know the cause why music was ordain'd!

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Was it not to refresh the mind of man

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: After his studies or his usual pain?

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Then give me leave to read philosophy,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And while I pause, serve in your harmony.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: To strive for that which resteth in my choice:

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: I am no breeching scholar in the schools;

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: But learn my lessons as I please myself.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down:

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Take you your instrument, play you the whiles;

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: That will be never: tune your instrument.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Where left we last?

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Here, madam:

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: 'Hic ibat Simois; hic est Sigeia tellus;

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.'

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Construe them.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: 'Hic ibat,' as I told you before, 'Simois,' I am

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Lucentio, 'hic est,' son unto Vincentio of Pisa,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: 'Sigeia tellus,' disguised thus to get your love;

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: 'Hic steterat,' and that Lucentio that comes

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: a-wooing, 'Priami,' is my man Tranio, 'regia,'

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: bearing my port, 'celsa senis,' that we might

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: beguile the old pantaloon.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Madam, my instrument's in tune.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Let's hear. O fie! the treble jars.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Now let me see if I can construe it: 'Hic ibat

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Simois,' I know you not, 'hic est Sigeia tellus,' I

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: trust you not; 'Hic steterat Priami,' take heed

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: he hear us not, 'regia,' presume not, 'celsa senis,'

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: despair not.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Madam, 'tis now in tune.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: All but the base.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: The base is right; 'tis the base knave that jars.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Aside

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: How fiery and forward our pedant is!

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Now, for my life, the knave doth court my love:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Mistrust it not: for, sure, AEacides

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Was Ajax, call'd so from his grandfather.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: I must believe my master; else, I promise you,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: I should be arguing still upon that doubt:

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: But let it rest. Now, Licio, to you:

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Good masters, take it not unkindly, pray,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: That I have been thus pleasant with you both.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: You may go walk, and give me leave a while:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: My lessons make no music in three parts.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Are you so formal, sir? well, I must wait,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Aside

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And watch withal; for, but I be deceived,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Our fine musician groweth amorous.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Madam, before you touch the instrument,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: To learn the order of my fingering,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: I must begin with rudiments of art;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: To teach you gamut in a briefer sort,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: More pleasant, pithy and effectual,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Than hath been taught by any of my trade:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And there it is in writing, fairly drawn.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Why, I am past my gamut long ago.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: [Reads]  ''Gamut' I am, the ground of all accord,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: 'A re,' to Plead Hortensio's passion;

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: 'B mi,' Bianca, take him for thy lord,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: 'C fa ut,' that loves with all affection:

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: 'D sol re,' one clef, two notes have I:

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: 'E la mi,' show pity, or I die.'

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Call you this gamut? tut, I like it not:

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Old fashions please me best; I am not so nice,

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: To change true rules for old inventions.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Mistress, your father prays you leave your books

speaker: Servant
text_entry: And help to dress your sister's chamber up:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: You know to-morrow is the wedding-day.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Farewell, sweet masters both; I must be gone.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Exeunt BIANCA and Servant

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: But I have cause to pry into this pedant:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Methinks he looks as though he were in love:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humble

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: To cast thy wandering eyes on every stale,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Seize thee that list: if once I find thee ranging,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: SCENE II. Padua. Before BAPTISTA'S house.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Enter BAPTISTA, GREMIO, TRANIO, KATHARINA, BIANCA, LUCENTIO, and others, attendants

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: [To TRANIO]  Signior Lucentio, this is the

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: 'pointed day.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: That Katharina and Petruchio should be married,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And yet we hear not of our son-in-law.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: What will be said? what mockery will it be,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: To want the bridegroom when the priest attends

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: To speak the ceremonial rites of marriage!

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: What says Lucentio to this shame of ours?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: No shame but mine: I must, forsooth, be forced

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: To give my hand opposed against my heart

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Unto a mad-brain rudesby full of spleen;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Who woo'd in haste and means to wed at leisure.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I told you, I, he was a frantic fool,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And, to be noted for a merry man,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: He'll woo a thousand, 'point the day of marriage,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Make feasts, invite friends, and proclaim the banns;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Yet never means to wed where he hath woo'd.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Now must the world point at poor Katharina,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And say, 'Lo, there is mad Petruchio's wife,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: If it would please him come and marry her!'

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Patience, good Katharina, and Baptista too.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Upon my life, Petruchio means but well,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Whatever fortune stays him from his word:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Would Katharina had never seen him though!

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Exit weeping, followed by BIANCA and others

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Go, girl; I cannot blame thee now to weep;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: For such an injury would vex a very saint,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Much more a shrew of thy impatient humour.

speaker: BAPTISTA
