text_entry: Enter BIONDELLO

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Master, master! news, old news, and such news as

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: you never heard of!

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Is it new and old too? how may that be?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Why, is it not news, to hear of Petruchio's coming?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Is he come?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Why, no, sir.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: What then?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: He is coming.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: When will he be here?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: But say, what to thine old news?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an old

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: jerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned, a pair

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: of boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: another laced, an old rusty sword ta'en out of the

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: town-armory, with a broken hilt, and chapeless;

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: with two broken points: his horse hipped with an

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred;

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: besides, possessed with the glanders and like to mose

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: in the chine; troubled with the lampass, infected

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: with the fashions, full of wingdalls, sped with

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: spavins, rayed with yellows, past cure of the fives,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: stark spoiled with the staggers, begnawn with the

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: bots, swayed in the back and shoulder-shotten;

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: near-legged before and with, a half-chequed bit

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: and a head-stall of sheeps leather which, being

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: often burst and now repaired with knots; one girth

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: six time pieced and a woman's crupper of velure,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: which hath two letters for her name fairly set down

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: in studs, and here and there pieced with packthread.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Who comes with him?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: O, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparisoned

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: like the horse; with a linen stock on one leg and a

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a red

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: and blue list; an old hat and 'the humour of forty

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: fancies' pricked in't for a feather: a monster, a

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: footboy or a gentleman's lackey.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: 'Tis some odd humour pricks him to this fashion;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-apparell'd.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Why, sir, he comes not.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Didst thou not say he comes?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Who? that Petruchio came?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Ay, that Petruchio came.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Why, that's all one.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Nay, by Saint Jamy,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: I hold you a penny,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: A horse and a man

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Is more than one,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: And yet not many.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Enter PETRUCHIO and GRUMIO

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Come, where be these gallants? who's at home?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: You are welcome, sir.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And yet I come not well.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And yet you halt not.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Not so well apparell'd

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: As I wish you were.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Were it better, I should rush in thus.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But where is Kate? where is my lovely bride?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And wherefore gaze this goodly company,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As if they saw some wondrous monument,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Some comet or unusual prodigy?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding-day:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: First were we sad, fearing you would not come;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Now sadder, that you come so unprovided.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: An eye-sore to our solemn festival!

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And tells us, what occasion of import

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Hath all so long detain'd you from your wife,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And sent you hither so unlike yourself?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Sufficeth I am come to keep my word,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Though in some part enforced to digress;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Which, at more leisure, I will so excuse

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As you shall well be satisfied withal.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But where is Kate? I stay too long from her:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: The morning wears, 'tis time we were at church.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: See not your bride in these unreverent robes:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Go to my chamber; Put on clothes of mine.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Not I, believe me: thus I'll visit her.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Good sooth, even thus; therefore ha' done with words:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To me she's married, not unto my clothes:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Could I repair what she will wear in me,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As I can change these poor accoutrements,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But what a fool am I to chat with you,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: When I should bid good morrow to my bride,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And seal the title with a lovely kiss!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Exeunt PETRUCHIO and GRUMIO

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: He hath some meaning in his mad attire:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: We will persuade him, be it possible,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To put on better ere he go to church.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I'll after him, and see the event of this.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Exeunt BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and attendants

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: But to her love concerneth us to add

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Her father's liking: which to bring to pass,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: As I before unparted to your worship,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I am to get a man,--whate'er he be,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: It skills not much. we'll fit him to our turn,--

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And he shall be Vincentio of Pisa;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And make assurance here in Padua

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Of greater sums than I have promised.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: So shall you quietly enjoy your hope,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And marry sweet Bianca with consent.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Were it not that my fellow-school-master

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: 'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage;

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Which once perform'd, let all the world say no,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: I'll keep mine own, despite of all the world.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: That by degrees we mean to look into,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And watch our vantage in this business:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: We'll over-reach the greybeard, Gremio,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: The narrow-prying father, Minola,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: The quaint musician, amorous Licio;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: All for my master's sake, Lucentio.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Re-enter GREMIO

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Signior Gremio, came you from the church?

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: As willingly as e'er I came from school.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: A bridegroom say you? 'tis a groom indeed,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Curster than she? why, 'tis impossible.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Why he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Tut, she's a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Should ask, if Katharina should be his wife,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: 'Ay, by gogs-wouns,' quoth he; and swore so loud,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: That, all-amazed, the priest let fall the book;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And, as he stoop'd again to take it up,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: The mad-brain'd bridegroom took him such a cuff

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: That down fell priest and book and book and priest:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: 'Now take them up,' quoth he, 'if any list.'

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: What said the wench when he rose again?

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Trembled and shook; for why, he stamp'd and swore,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: As if the vicar meant to cozen him.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: But after many ceremonies done,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: He calls for wine: 'A health!' quoth he, as if

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: He had been aboard, carousing to his mates

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: After a storm; quaff'd off the muscadel

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And threw the sops all in the sexton's face;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Having no other reason

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: But that his beard grew thin and hungerly

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And seem'd to ask him sops as he was drinking.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: This done, he took the bride about the neck

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And kiss'd her lips with such a clamorous smack

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: That at the parting all the church did echo:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And I seeing this came thence for very shame;

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: And after me, I know, the rout is coming.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Such a mad marriage never was before:

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Hark, hark! I hear the minstrels play.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Music

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Re-enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, BIANCA, BAPTISTA, HORTENSIO, GRUMIO, and Train

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I know you think to dine with me to-day,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And have prepared great store of wedding cheer;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But so it is, my haste doth call me hence,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And therefore here I mean to take my leave.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Is't possible you will away to-night?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I must away to-day, before night come:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Make it no wonder; if you knew my business,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You would entreat me rather go than stay.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And, honest company, I thank you all,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That have beheld me give away myself

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Dine with my father, drink a health to me;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For I must hence; and farewell to you all.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: It may not be.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Let me entreat you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: It cannot be.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Let me entreat you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I am content.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Are you content to stay?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I am content you shall entreat me stay;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Now, if you love me, stay.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Grumio, my horse.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Ay, sir, they be ready: the oats have eaten the horses.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Nay, then,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Do what thou canst, I will not go to-day;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: No, nor to-morrow, not till I please myself.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: The door is open, sir; there lies your way;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: You may be jogging whiles your boots are green;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: 'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: That take it on you at the first so roundly.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O Kate, content thee; prithee, be not angry.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I will be angry: what hast thou to do?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Father, be quiet; he shall stay my leisure.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.

speaker: KATARINA
text_entry: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner:

speaker: KATARINA
text_entry: I see a woman may be made a fool,

speaker: KATARINA
text_entry: If she had not a spirit to resist.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Obey the bride, you that attend on her;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Go to the feast, revel and domineer,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Carouse full measure to her maidenhead,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I will be master of what is mine own:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: She is my goods, my chattels; she is my house,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: My household stuff, my field, my barn,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: My horse, my ox, my ass, my any thing;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And here she stands, touch her whoever dare;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I'll bring mine action on the proudest he

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That stops my way in Padua. Grumio,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Rescue thy mistress, if thou be a man.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: thee, Kate:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I'll buckler thee against a million.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Exeunt PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, and GRUMIO

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Of all mad matches never was the like.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Neighbours and friends, though bride and

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: bridegroom wants

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: For to supply the places at the table,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: You know there wants no junkets at the feast.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Lucentio, you shall supply the bridegroom's place:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And let Bianca take her sister's room.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: SCENE I. PETRUCHIO'S country house.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Enter GRUMIO

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: all foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? was ever

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: man so rayed? was ever man so weary? I am sent

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: before to make a fire, and they are coming after to

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: warm them. Now, were not I a little pot and soon

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me: but

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I, with blowing the fire, shall warm myself; for,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: considering the weather, a taller man than I will

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: take cold. Holla, ho! Curtis.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Enter CURTIS

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Who is that calls so coldly?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: A piece of ice: if thou doubt it, thou mayst slide

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: but my head and my neck. A fire good Curtis.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: O, ay, Curtis, ay: and therefore fire, fire; cast

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: on no water.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: She was, good Curtis, before this frost: but, thou

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: knowest, winter tames man, woman and beast; for it

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: hath tamed my old master and my new mistress and

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: myself, fellow Curtis.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Am I but three inches? why, thy horn is a foot; and

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: so long am I at the least. But wilt thou make a

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: fire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: whose hand, she being now at hand, thou shalt soon

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine; and

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: therefore fire: do thy duty, and have thy duty; for

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: There's fire ready; and therefore, good Grumio, the news.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Why, 'Jack, boy! ho! boy!' and as much news as

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: will thaw.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Come, you are so full of cony-catching!

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Why, therefore fire; for I have caught extreme cold.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Where's the cook? is supper ready, the house

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept; the

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: serving-men in their new fustian, their white

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: stockings, and every officer his wedding-garment on?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Be the jacks fair within, the jills fair without,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: the carpets laid, and every thing in order?

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: All ready; and therefore, I pray thee, news.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: First, know, my horse is tired; my master and

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: mistress fallen out.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: How?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Out of their saddles into the dirt; and thereby

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: hangs a tale.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Let's ha't, good Grumio.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Lend thine ear.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Here.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: There.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Strikes him

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: This is to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale: and this

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: cuff was but to knock at your ear, and beseech

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: listening. Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down a

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress,--

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Both of one horse?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: What's that to thee?

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Why, a horse.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed me,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell and she

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: under her horse; thou shouldst have heard in how

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: miry a place, how she was bemoiled, how he left her

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: with the horse upon her, how he beat me because

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: her horse stumbled, how she waded through the dirt

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: to pluck him off me, how he swore, how she prayed,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: that never prayed before, how I cried, how the

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: horses ran away, how her bridle was burst, how I

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: lost my crupper, with many things of worthy memory,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: which now shall die in oblivion and thou return

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: unexperienced to thy grave.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: By this reckoning he is more shrew than she.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Ay; and that thou and the proudest of you all shall

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: find when he comes home. But what talk I of this?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Walter, Sugarsop and the rest: let their heads be

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: sleekly combed their blue coats brushed and their

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: garters of an indifferent knit: let them curtsy

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: with their left legs and not presume to touch a hair

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: of my master's horse-tail till they kiss their

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: hands. Are they all ready?

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: They are.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Call them forth.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master to

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: countenance my mistress.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Why, she hath a face of her own.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Who knows not that?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: countenance her.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: I call them forth to credit her.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Enter four or five Serving-men

speaker: NATHANIEL
text_entry: Welcome home, Grumio!

speaker: PHILIP
text_entry: How now, Grumio!

speaker: JOSEPH
text_entry: What, Grumio!

speaker: NICHOLAS
text_entry: Fellow Grumio!

speaker: NATHANIEL
text_entry: How now, old lad?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Welcome, you;--how now, you;-- what, you;--fellow,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: you;--and thus much for greeting. Now, my spruce

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: companions, is all ready, and all things neat?

speaker: NATHANIEL
text_entry: All things is ready. How near is our master?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: E'en at hand, alighted by this; and therefore be

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: not--Cock's passion, silence! I hear my master.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Enter PETRUCHIO and KATHARINA

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Where be these knaves? What, no man at door

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To hold my stirrup nor to take my horse!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: ALL SERVING-MEN Here, here, sir; here, sir.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! here, sir!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You logger-headed and unpolish'd grooms!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What, no attendance? no regard? no duty?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Here, sir; as foolish as I was before.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You peasant swain! you whoreson malt-horse drudge!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Did I not bid thee meet me in the park,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Nathaniel's coat, sir, was not fully made,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: And Gabriel's pumps were all unpink'd i' the heel;

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: There was no link to colour Peter's hat,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing:

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: There were none fine but Adam, Ralph, and Gregory;

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly;

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Exeunt Servants

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Singing

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Where is the life that late I led--

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Where are those--Sit down, Kate, and welcome.--

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Sound, sound, sound, sound!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Re-enter Servants with supper

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, when, I say? Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Off with my boots, you rogues! you villains, when?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Sings

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: It was the friar of orders grey,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As he forth walked on his way:--

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Out, you rogue! you pluck my foot awry:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Take that, and mend the plucking off the other.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Strikes him

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Be merry, Kate. Some water, here; what, ho!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Where's my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: One, Kate, that you must kiss, and be acquainted with.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Enter one with water

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You whoreson villain! will you let it fall?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Strikes him

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: A whoreson beetle-headed, flap-ear'd knave!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Come, Kate, sit down; I know you have a stomach.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Will you give thanks, sweet Kate; or else shall I?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What's this? mutton?

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Who brought it?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: I.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: 'Tis burnt; and so is all the meat.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What dogs are these! Where is the rascal cook?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And serve it thus to me that love it not?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Theretake it to you, trenchers, cups, and all;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Throws the meat,  and c. about the stage

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You heedless joltheads and unmanner'd slaves!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What, do you grumble? I'll be with you straight.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: The meat was well, if you were so contented.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And I expressly am forbid to touch it,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For it engenders choler, planteth anger;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And better 'twere that both of us did fast,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Since, of ourselves, ourselves are choleric,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Than feed it with such over-roasted flesh.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Be patient; to-morrow 't shall be mended,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And, for this night, we'll fast for company:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Re-enter Servants severally

speaker: NATHANIEL
text_entry: Peter, didst ever see the like?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: He kills her in her own humour.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Re-enter CURTIS

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Where is he?

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: In her chamber, making a sermon of continency to her;

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: And rails, and swears, and rates, that she, poor soul,

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak,

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: And sits as one new-risen from a dream.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Away, away! for he is coming hither.

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CURTIS
text_entry: Re-enter PETRUCHIO

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thus have I politicly begun my reign,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And 'tis my hope to end successfully.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: My falcon now is sharp and passing empty;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And till she stoop she must not be full-gorged,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For then she never looks upon her lure.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Another way I have to man my haggard,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To make her come and know her keeper's call,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That bate and beat and will not be obedient.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: She eat no meat to-day, nor none shall eat;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Last night she slept not, nor to-night she shall not;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As with the meat, some undeserved fault

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I'll find about the making of the bed;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: This way the coverlet, another way the sheets:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Ay, and amid this hurly I intend

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: That all is done in reverend care of her;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And in conclusion she shall watch all night:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And with the clamour keep her still awake.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: This is a way to kill a wife with kindness;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: He that knows better how to tame a shrew,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Now let him speak: 'tis charity to show.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: SCENE II. Padua. Before BAPTISTA'S house.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Enter TRANIO and HORTENSIO

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Is't possible, friend Licio, that Mistress Bianca

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Enter BIANCA and LUCENTIO

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: What, master, read you? first resolve me that.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: I read that I profess, the Art to Love.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: And may you prove, sir, master of your art!

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Quick proceeders, marry! Now, tell me, I pray,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: You that durst swear at your mistress Bianca

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Loved none in the world so well as Lucentio.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: O despiteful love! unconstant womankind!

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I tell thee, Licio, this is wonderful.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Mistake no more: I am not Licio,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Nor a musician, as I seem to be;

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: But one that scorn to live in this disguise,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: For such a one as leaves a gentleman,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And makes a god of such a cullion:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Know, sir, that I am call'd Hortensio.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Signior Hortensio, I have often heard

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Of your entire affection to Bianca;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I will with you, if you be so contented,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: See, how they kiss and court! Signior Lucentio,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Never to woo her no more, but do forswear her,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: As one unworthy all the former favours

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: That I have fondly flatter'd her withal.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And here I take the unfeigned oath,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Never to marry with her though she would entreat:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Fie on her! see, how beastly she doth court him!

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: For me, that I may surely keep mine oath,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: I will be married to a wealthy widow,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Shall win my love: and so I take my leave,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: In resolution as I swore before.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: As 'longeth to a lover's blessed case!

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And have forsworn you with Hortensio.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Tranio, you jest: but have you both forsworn me?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Mistress, we have.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Then we are rid of Licio.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I' faith, he'll have a lusty widow now,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: That shall be wood and wedded in a day.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: God give him joy!

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Ay, and he'll tame her.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: He says so, Tranio.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: The taming-school! what, is there such a place?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Enter BIONDELLO

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: O master, master, I have watch'd so long

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: That I am dog-weary: but at last I spied

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: An ancient angel coming down the hill,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Will serve the turn.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: What is he, Biondello?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Master, a mercatante, or a pedant,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: I know not what; but format in apparel,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: In gait and countenance surely like a father.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And what of him, Tranio?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: If he be credulous and trust my tale,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And give assurance to Baptista Minola,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: As if he were the right Vincentio

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Take in your love, and then let me alone.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Exeunt LUCENTIO and BIANCA

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Enter a Pedant

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: God save you, sir!

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And you, sir! you are welcome.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two:

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: But then up farther, and as for as Rome;

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: What countryman, I pray?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Of Mantua.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Of Mantua, sir? marry, God forbid!

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And come to Padua, careless of your life?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: My life, sir! how, I pray? for that goes hard.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: 'Tis death for any one in Mantua

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Your ships are stay'd at Venice, and the duke,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: 'Tis, marvel, but that you are but newly come,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: You might have heard it else proclaim'd about.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Alas! sir, it is worse for me than so;

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: For I have bills for money by exchange

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: From Florence and must here deliver them.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Well, sir, to do you courtesy,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: This will I do, and this I will advise you:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been,

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Pisa renowned for grave citizens.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Among them know you one Vincentio?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: I know him not, but I have heard of him;

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: A merchant of incomparable wealth.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: He is my father, sir; and, sooth to say,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: [Aside]  As much as an apple doth an oyster,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: and all one.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To save your life in this extremity,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: This favour will I do you for his sake;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And think it not the worst of an your fortunes

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: That you are like to Sir Vincentio.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: His name and credit shall you undertake,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: And in my house you shall be friendly lodged:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Look that you take upon you as you should;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: You understand me, sir: so shall you stay

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Till you have done your business in the city:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: If this be courtesy, sir, accept of it.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: O sir, I do; and will repute you ever

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: The patron of my life and liberty.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Then go with me to make the matter good.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: This, by the way, I let you understand;

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: my father is here look'd for every day,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To pass assurance of a dower in marriage

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: 'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: In all these circumstances I'll instruct you:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: SCENE III. A room in PETRUCHIO'S house.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Enter KATHARINA and GRUMIO

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: What, did he marry me to famish me?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Beggars, that come unto my father's door,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Upon entreaty have a present aims;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: If not, elsewhere they meet with charity:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: But I, who never knew how to entreat,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Nor never needed that I should entreat,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: With oath kept waking and with brawling fed:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And that which spites me more than all these wants,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: He does it under name of perfect love;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: As who should say, if I should sleep or eat,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: 'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I prithee go and get me some repast;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I care not what, so it be wholesome food.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: What say you to a neat's foot?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: 'Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I fear it is too choleric a meat.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: How say you to a fat tripe finely broil'd?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I cannot tell; I fear 'tis choleric.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Beats him

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: That feed'st me with the very name of meat:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: That triumph thus upon my misery!

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Go, get thee gone, I say.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Enter PETRUCHIO and HORTENSIO with meat

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Mistress, what cheer?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Faith, as cold as can be.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Here love; thou see'st how diligent I am

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What, not a word? Nay, then thou lovest it not;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And all my pains is sorted to no proof.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Here, take away this dish.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I pray you, let it stand.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: The poorest service is repaid with thanks;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I thank you, sir.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Signior Petruchio, fie! you are to blame.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Come, mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: [Aside]  Eat it up all, Hortensio, if thou lovest me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Much good do it unto thy gentle heart!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Kate, eat apace: and now, my honey love,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Will we return unto thy father's house

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And revel it as bravely as the best,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: With silken coats and caps and golden rings,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: With ruffs and cuffs and fardingales and things;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: With scarfs and fans and double change of bravery,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: With amber bracelets, beads and all this knavery.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What, hast thou dined? The tailor stays thy leisure,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Enter Tailor

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Lay forth the gown.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Enter Haberdasher

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What news with you, sir?

speaker: Haberdasher
text_entry: Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, this was moulded on a porringer;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: A velvet dish: fie, fie! 'tis lewd and filthy:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Away with it! come, let me have a bigger.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I'll have no bigger: this doth fit the time,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And gentlewomen wear such caps as these

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: When you are gentle, you shall have one too,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And not till then.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: [Aside]  That will not be in haste.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And speak I will; I am no child, no babe:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Your betters have endured me say my mind,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Or else my heart concealing it will break,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And rather than it shall, I will be free

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, thou say'st true; it is a paltry cap,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I love thee well, in that thou likest it not.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Love me or love me not, I like the cap;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And it I will have, or I will have none.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Exit Haberdasher

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thy gown? why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What's this? a sleeve? 'tis like a demi-cannon:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What, up and down, carved like an apple-tart?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Like to a censer in a barber's shop:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, what, i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: [Aside]  I see she's like to have neither cap nor gown.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: You bid me make it orderly and well,

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: According to the fashion and the time.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Marry, and did; but if you be remember'd,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I did not bid you mar it to the time.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Go, hop me over every kennel home,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For you shall hop without my custom, sir:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I'll none of it: hence! make your best of it.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I never saw a better-fashion'd gown,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, true; he means to make a puppet of thee.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: She says your worship means to make

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: a puppet of her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: thou thimble,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr'd her gown.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: Your worship is deceived; the gown is made

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: Just as my master had direction:

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: Grumio gave order how it should be done.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: But how did you desire it should be made?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: But did you not request to have it cut?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Thou hast faced many things.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: I have.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Face not me: thou hast braved many men; brave not

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: me; I will neither be faced nor braved. I say unto

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: thee, I bid thy master cut out the gown; but I did

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: not bid him cut it to pieces: ergo, thou liest.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Read it.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: [Reads]  'Imprimis, a loose-bodied gown:'

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sew me in

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a bottom

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: of brown thread: I said a gown.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Proceed.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: [Reads]  'With a small compassed cape:'

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I confess the cape.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: [Reads]  'With a trunk sleeve:'

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I confess two sleeves.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: [Reads]  'The sleeves curiously cut.'

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Ay, there's the villany.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: sewed up again; and that I'll prove upon thee,

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: This is true that I say: an I had thee

speaker: Tailor
text_entry: in place where, thou shouldst know it.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: I am for thee straight: take thou the

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: bill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: God-a-mercy, Grumio! then he shall have no odds.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: You are i' the right, sir: 'tis for my mistress.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Villain, not for thy life: take up my mistress'

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: gown for thy master's use!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for:

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use!

speaker: GRUMIO
text_entry: O, fie, fie, fie!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: [Aside]  Hortensio, say thou wilt see the tailor paid.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Go take it hence; be gone, and say no more.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Take no unkindness of his hasty words:

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Away! I say; commend me to thy master.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Exit Tailor

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Well, come, my Kate; we will unto your father's

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Even in these honest mean habiliments:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: So honour peereth in the meanest habit.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What is the jay more precious than the lark,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Because his fathers are more beautiful?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Or is the adder better than the eel,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Because his painted skin contents the eye?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: O, no, good Kate; neither art thou the worse

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For this poor furniture and mean array.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: if thou account'st it shame. lay it on me;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And therefore frolic: we will hence forthwith,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To feast and sport us at thy father's house.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Go, call my men, and let us straight to him;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And bring our horses unto Long-lane end;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: There will we mount, and thither walk on foot

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Let's see; I think 'tis now some seven o'clock,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And well we may come there by dinner-time.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And 'twill be supper-time ere you come there.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: It shall be seven ere I go to horse:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: You are still crossing it. Sirs, let't alone:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I will not go to-day; and ere I do,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: [Aside]  Why, so this gallant will command the sun.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: SCENE IV. Padua. Before BAPTISTA'S house.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Enter TRANIO, and the Pedant dressed like VINCENTIO

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Sir, this is the house: please it you that I call?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Ay, what else? and but I be deceived

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Signior Baptista may remember me,

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Near twenty years ago, in Genoa,

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: 'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: I warrant you.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Enter BIONDELLO

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: But, sir, here comes your boy;

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: 'Twere good he were school'd.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Now do your duty throughly, I advise you:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Tut, fear not me.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: I told him that your father was at Venice,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: And that you look'd for him this day in Padua.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Thou'rt a tall fellow: hold thee that to drink.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Here comes Baptista: set your countenance, sir.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Enter BAPTISTA and LUCENTIO

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Signior Baptista, you are happily met.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: To the Pedant

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I pray you stand good father to me now,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Give me Bianca for my patrimony.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Soft son!

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Sir, by your leave: having come to Padua

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Made me acquainted with a weighty cause

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Of love between your daughter and himself:

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: And, for the good report I hear of you

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: And for the love he beareth to your daughter

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: And she to him, to stay him not too long,

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: I am content, in a good father's care,

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: To have him match'd; and if you please to like

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: No worse than I, upon some agreement

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Me shall you find ready and willing

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: With one consent to have her so bestow'd;

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: For curious I cannot be with you,

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Right true it is, your son Lucentio here

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Doth love my daughter and she loveth him,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Or both dissemble deeply their affections:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And therefore, if you say no more than this,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: That like a father you will deal with him

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And pass my daughter a sufficient dower,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: The match is made, and all is done:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: We be affied and such assurance ta'en

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: As shall with either part's agreement stand?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Not in my house, Lucentio; for, you know,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants:

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And happily we might be interrupted.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Then at my lodging, an it like you:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: There doth my father lie; and there, this night,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: We'll pass the business privately and well.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Send for your daughter by your servant here:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: The worst is this, that, at so slender warning,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: It likes me well. Biondello, hie you home,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And bid Bianca make her ready straight;

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And, if you will, tell what hath happened,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Lucentio's father is arrived in Padua,

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: I pray the gods she may with all my heart!

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Exit BIONDELLO

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Welcome! one mess is like to be your cheer:

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Come, sir; we will better it in Pisa.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: I follow you.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Exeunt TRANIO, Pedant, and BAPTISTA

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Re-enter BIONDELLO

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Cambio!

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: What sayest thou, Biondello?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Biondello, what of that?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind, to

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: I pray thee, moralize them.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Then thus. Baptista is safe, talking with the

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: deceiving father of a deceitful son.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And what of him?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And then?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: The old priest of Saint Luke's church is at your

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: command at all hours.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And what of all this?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: I cannot tell; expect they are busied about a

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: 'cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum:' to the

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: church; take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: honest witnesses: If this be not that you look for,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell for

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: ever and a day.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Hearest thou, Biondello?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: stuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir: and so, adieu,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: sir. My master hath appointed me to go to Saint

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Luke's, to bid the priest be ready to come against

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: you come with your appendix.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: I may, and will, if she be so contented:

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: She will be pleased; then wherefore should I doubt?

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her:

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: SCENE V. A public road.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, HORTENSIO, and Servants

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Come on, i' God's name; once more toward our father's.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: The moon! the sun: it is not moonlight now.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: It shall be moon, or star, or what I list,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Or ere I journey to your father's house.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Go on, and fetch our horses back again.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Evermore cross'd and cross'd; nothing but cross'd!

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Say as he says, or we shall never go.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Forward, I pray, since we have come so far,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And be it moon, or sun, or what you please:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: An if you please to call it a rush-candle,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I say it is the moon.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: I know it is the moon.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Nay, then you lie: it is the blessed sun.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Then, God be bless'd, it is the blessed sun:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: But sun it is not, when you say it is not;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And the moon changes even as your mind.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: What you will have it named, even that it is;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: And so it shall be so for Katharina.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Well, forward, forward! thus the bowl should run,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And not unluckily against the bias.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: But, soft! company is coming here.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Enter VINCENTIO

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: To VINCENTIO

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Good morrow, gentle mistress: where away?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Such war of white and red within her cheeks!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: As those two eyes become that heavenly face?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: A' will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Whither away, or where is thy abode?

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Happy the parents of so fair a child;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Happier the man, whom favourable stars

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Allot thee for his lovely bed-fellow!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, wither'd,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes,

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: That have been so bedazzled with the sun

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: That everything I look on seemeth green:

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Now I perceive thou art a reverend father;

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Do, good old grandsire; and withal make known

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Which way thou travellest: if along with us,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: We shall be joyful of thy company.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Fair sir, and you my merry mistress,

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: That with your strange encounter much amazed me,

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: My name is call'd Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa;

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: And bound I am to Padua; there to visit

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: A son of mine, which long I have not seen.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: What is his name?

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Lucentio, gentle sir.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Happily we met; the happier for thy son.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And now by law, as well as reverend age,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I may entitle thee my loving father:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thy son by this hath married. Wonder not,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Nor be grieved: she is of good esteem,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Her dowery wealthy, and of worthy birth;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Beside, so qualified as may beseem

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: The spouse of any noble gentleman.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Let me embrace with old Vincentio,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: And wander we to see thy honest son,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: But is it true? or else is it your pleasure,

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Like pleasant travellers, to break a jest

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Upon the company you overtake?

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: I do assure thee, father, so it is.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Come, go along, and see the truth hereof;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Exeunt all but HORTENSIO

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Have to my widow! and if she be froward,

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: SCENE I. Padua. Before LUCENTIO'S house.

speaker: HORTENSIO
text_entry: GREMIO discovered. Enter behind BIONDELLO, LUCENTIO, and BIANCA

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Softly and swiftly, sir; for the priest is ready.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: I fly, Biondello: but they may chance to need thee

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: at home; therefore leave us.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Nay, faith, I'll see the church o' your back; and

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: then come back to my master's as soon as I can.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Exeunt LUCENTIO, BIANCA, and BIONDELLO

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, VINCENTIO, GRUMIO, with Attendants

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Sir, here's the door, this is Lucentio's house:

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: My father's bears more toward the market-place;

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: You shall not choose but drink before you go:

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: I think I shall command your welcome here,

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Knocks

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: They're busy within; you were best knock louder.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Pedant looks out of the window

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, to

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: make merry withal?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: need none, so long as I live.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous circumstances,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: I pray you, tell Signior Lucentio that his father is

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: looking out at the window.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Art thou his father?

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: [To VINCENTIO]  Why, how now, gentleman! why, this

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: is flat knavery, to take upon you another man's name.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Lay hands on the villain: I believe a' means to

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: cozen somebody in this city under my countenance.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Re-enter BIONDELLO

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: I have seen them in the church together: God send

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: 'em good shipping! But who is here? mine old

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: master Vincentio! now we are undone and brought to nothing.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: [Seeing BIONDELLO]

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Come hither, crack-hemp.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Hope I may choose, sir.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for I

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: never saw you before in all my life.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: thy master's father, Vincentio?

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: What, my old worshipful old master? yes, marry, sir:

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: see where he looks out of the window.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Is't so, indeed.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Beats BIONDELLO

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Help, help, help! here's a madman will murder me.

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Help, son! help, Signior Baptista!

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Exit from above

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: this controversy.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: They retire

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: Re-enter Pedant below; TRANIO, BAPTISTA, and Servants

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortal

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet! a velvet

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: hose! a scarlet cloak! and a copatain hat! O, I

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: am undone! I am undone! while I play the good

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: the university.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: How now! what's the matter?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: What, is the man lunatic?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: you think is his name?

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: His name! as if I knew not his name: I have brought

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: him up ever since he was three years old, and his

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: name is Tranio.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio and he is

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Lucentio! O, he hath murdered his master! Lay hold

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: on him, I charge you, in the duke's name. O, my

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Call forth an officer.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Enter one with an Officer

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista,

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: I charge you see that he be forthcoming.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Carry me to the gaol!

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: is the right Vincentio.

speaker: Pedant
text_entry: Swear, if thou darest.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Nay, I dare not swear it.

speaker: TRANIO
text_entry: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: O

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: monstrous villain!

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Re-enter BIONDELLO, with LUCENTIO and BIANCA

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: O! we are spoiled and--yonder he is: deny him,

speaker: BIONDELLO
text_entry: forswear him, or else we are all undone.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: [Kneeling]  Pardon, sweet father.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Lives my sweet son?

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Exeunt BIONDELLO, TRANIO, and Pedant, as fast as may be

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Pardon, dear father.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: How hast thou offended?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Where is Lucentio?

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Here's Lucentio,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Right son to the right Vincentio;

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Here's packing, with a witness to deceive us all!

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Where is that damned villain Tranio,

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: That faced and braved me in this matter so?

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

speaker: BIANCA
text_entry: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Made me exchange my state with Tranio,

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: While he did bear my countenance in the town;

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: And happily I have arrived at the last

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Unto the wished haven of my bliss.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: What Tranio did, myself enforced him to;

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: me to the gaol.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: But do you hear, sir? have you married my daughter

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: without asking my good will?

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: I will in, to be revenged for this villany.

speaker: VINCENTIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.

speaker: BAPTISTA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.

speaker: LUCENTIO
text_entry: Exeunt LUCENTIO and BIANCA

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest,

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.

speaker: GREMIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
text_entry: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

speaker: KATHARINA
text_entry: What, in the midst of the street?
